No, I don't think it's a bug. Further down in the same method body
it resolves the class:

if (resolve)
	resolveClass(c);
return c;

The method wants to check to see if the class should be
excluded before loading and resolving it. Otherwise, other classes
that the class depends upon might be loaded, but which cannot
be unloaded if the class is subsequently excluded by JUnit's class
exclusion list.

<off-topic>
If you really want to write your own JUnit class loader I would
recommend that you write it from scratch, and create an implementation
that only overrides ClassLoader.findClass(String name), specifying
the classes you want to include rather than classes you want to exclude.
Keep the system CLASSPATH set to just the classes you need for your test
runner and nothing else. This would align your class loader to Sun
recommendations on such things. I don't know why JUnit's class loading
is written the way it is, perhaps someone could enlighten me, but I
expect it is because the code pre-dates JDK 1.2, when the Java class
loading model was no as stable.
</off-topic>

Malcolm
